references.W14IUC99USGP: IUCN. 2014. The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2014.1. http://www.iucnredlist.org. Downloaded March 2016.
references.A99HIG01USGP: Highton, R. 1999. Geographic protein variation and speciation in the salamanders of the Plethodon cinereus group with the description of two new species. Herpetologica 55:43-90.
references.B87GRE01NAUS: Green, N. B., and T. K. Pauley. 1987. Amphibians and reptiles in West Virginia. University of Pittsburg Press, Pittsburg, Pennsylvania. xi + 241 pp.
references.A80PAU01USGP: Pauley, T.K. 1980. Field notes on the distribution of terrestrial amphicians and reptiles of the West Virginia Mountains above 975 meters. Proceedings of the West Virginia Academy of Science. 52:84-92.
references.B05BEA04USGP: Beamer, D.A. and M.J. Lannoo. 2005. Plethodon hoffmani (Highton 1972 "1971"), Valley and Ridge Salamander. In Lannoo (Ed.), Amphibian Declines. The Conservation Status of United States Species, University of California Press, Berkeley, CA. p. 812-814.
references.A86HIG04SEGP: Highton, R. 1986. Plethodon hoffmani. Catalogue of American Amphibians and Reptiles. 392:1-2.

habitat_description: The Valley and Ridge salamander is found in the physiographic region from which it gets its name and is associated with hillside slopes of mature mixed hardwood forest.  They can be found under rocks, logs, and other surface cover along ravines and mountain slopes (Green and Pauley 1987, Petranka 1998, Beamer and Lannoo 2005).  They are sometimes found in the twilight zones of West Virginia caves (Petranka 1998). The majoity of sites inhabited by P. hoffmani are dry and well drained (Highton 1999, Beamer and Lannoo 2005). They have been collected from sites as high as 1402 meters (Pauley 1980, Petranka 1998). Courtship and mating probably occur in spring. A clutch of 3-8 eggs is laid in spring.  The larval stage is passed in the egg and the female attends the clutch. Hatching occurs in August-September and sexual maturity is reached in 2-3 years.
